p: The correlation between psychological factors and primary dysmenorrhea has been thoroughly described in the literature. 63, 64 The experience of recurrent menstrual pain increases the risk of mental disorders and especially stress, anxiety, and depression, but also alcohol abuse and somatic symptoms disorders. 64 In addition, the comorbidity of dysmenorrhea and depression may contribute to an increased focus on symptoms and by extent on the perceived intensity of pain. 63, 65
